body.p: Ben Fenton-Smith is a lecturer in the School of Languages and Linguistics at Griffith University in Brisbane, Australia, and was formerly Assistant Director of the English Language Institute at Kanda University of International Studies, Japan. He is currently involved in the development of, and research into, a university-wide English language proficiency strategy for Griffith University’s international student body.

Nathalie Gagné is a Pedagogical Counsellor in prior learning assessment and recognition (PLAR) for continuing education at Cégep Limoilou in Quebec City, Canada. Her work involves defining mandates and assigning them to content specialists as well as training, supervising and supporting staff in developing appropriate evaluation instruments used in PLAR.

Philip Hiver teaches at the International Graduate School of English in Seoul, Korea, where he is involved in pre- and in-service teacher-training. He holds an MA in Applied Linguistics from the University of Nottingham, UK. His research interests are language teacher identity, and the motivation and cognition surrounding foreign-language teacher development.

SuHua Huang received a PhD in Reading Education from the University of Oklahoma, USA. Currently, she is an assistant professor at Midwestern State University, Texas, USA, where she teaches children’s and adolescent literature and reading diagnosis. Her research focused reading motivation and literacy strategies for elementary school populations.

Jonathan Newton is a senior lecturer in the School of Linguistics and Applied Language Studies, Victoria University of Wellington, New Zealand. His research focuses on language teaching for the workplace, classroom-based SLA research, and intercultural language teaching.

Susan Parks is Associate Professor at Université Laval, Quebec City, Canada, where she is involved in second language teacher education. She is particularly interested in classroom-based research, including teaching practices related to the use of information and communication technologies.

Paul Stapleton is an Associate Professor in the Department of English at the Hong Kong Institute of Education, Hong Kong. He is currently interested in the impact of technology on the composing behaviour of second language writers.

Michael John Torpey is the Director of the English Language Institute at Kanda University of International Studies, Japan. He received his doctorate in education from Teachers College, Columbia University, New York, USA. His research interests include conflict resolution, social organizational psychology, educational program management, professional development and second language teacher education.

Feng Xiao is a PhD student in the Department of Modern Languages at Carnegie Mellon University, USA. His research interests include pragmatic approach to second language acquisition and classroom-based research.
